div.p: RABBI or Rabbins, a title which the Pharisees and doctors of the law among the Jews assumed, and literally fignifies mqflers or excellents.

There were several gradations before they arrived at the dignity of a rabbin ; which was not conferred till they had acquired the prcfoundest knowledge of the law and the traditions.bi≈øected of does not, however, appear that there was any fixed age or previous examination nccessary; but when a man had distinguished himsels by his skill in the written and oral law, and passed through the subordinate degrees, he was faluted a rabbin by the public voice.

Among the modern Jews, for near 700 years past, the learned men retain no other title than that of rabbi, or rabbins ; they have great respect paid them, have the first places or seats in their synagogues, determine all matters of controversy, and frequently pronounce upon civil affairs ; they have even power f o excommunicate the disobedient.
